awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: The Road (not) Taken: Selection of Legal Rules on the U.S. Supreme Court
awd_abstract_narration:
When the United States Supreme Court hears a case, it must determine not only who wins and loses, but what legal rule justifies that result. In fact, it is this rule - the language in the opinion that defines legal and illegal conduct - not the case outcome that constitutes the Court?s policy and influences the subsequent behavior of numerous other political actors.  Unlike most work on legal rules, this project recognizes that justices normally select their chosen rule from a limited range of proffered options. Consequently, it is among the first to argue that the justices? choices over rules are driven, at least in part, by the nature of the rules themselves. In particular, the project explores three questions: How do the justices select among the legal rules presented to them? What role does the specificity and legal soundness of the potential rules play in their decision? How do these rule attributes interact with concerns about policy impact, opinion quality, and compliance in the lower courts?

To answer these questions, the project generates original quantitative and qualitative data, including the first collection of the actual legal rules suggested to the justices by case participants. This dataset spans five decades, includes a range of legal issues, and is likely to be of interest to those who study legal rules, court opinions, and judicial decision-making more broadly. When combined with an examination of the private papers of several members of the Burger Court (1969-1985), the project should help illuminate the extent to which Supreme Court justices are motivated by policy outcome, policy compliance, and jurisprudential concerns, thus offering new insights into ongoing debates about the relative influence of law and politics on the U.S. Supreme Court.

por.por_cntn:
When the justices of the U.S. Supreme Court issue a decision, they must determine not only who wins or loses the case, but what legal principle justifies that result. It is this principle - often termed a "legal rule" - which is the heart of the policy made by the Court. I argue that the justices select their favored rule from among the options presented to them by case participants, and the project explores what drives this choice.

The findings indicate that the selection of legal rules is motivated by a complex mix of factors, including the ideological predispositions of the justices and the legal quality of the rules. The results also reveal that, because the justices rarely develop their own legal rules, they are not unfettered creators of legal policy, instead making their decisions based upon the rule choices offered by litigants. Finally, the findings suggest that the justices do not use legal rules as a means to control other courts in the judicial branch.

Along with a new database of legal rules from five hundred cases, which will be made available to the general public, and a completed dissertation, the project has generated a conference presentation and an article currently being prepared for  journal submission. Two additional conference presentations, two additional articles, and a book are also planned. 

By focusing on legal rules, this project directly addresses a key mechanism of Supreme Court policy-making. In so doing, it speaks to broader questions about the role of the Court in our democracy and its ability to develop national policy as the justices see fit.

 


Last Modified: 10/12/2012
Modified by: Thomas G Walker
